dialogue.statement: Hello! What brings you in today? Feel free to share anything on your mind.
Hey, so I've been feeling really overwhelmed with my math class. We use this program called Aleks, and it's just been eating up all my time and stressing me out.
It sounds like the math class and using Aleks are causing you a lot of stress. What's been the most challenging part about managing this workload?
client: Honestly, it's just how relentless Aleks is. The topics never seem to end, and I can't keep up with everything else I need to do. It's like I barely have time to breathe.

statement.reasoning: The client has shared a detailed story about their experiences and challenges with the Aleks math program, including emotional responses and specific contextual details. There is clear rapport and an understanding of the client's concerns, indicating the goals of the Exploring phase have been met.

dialogue.statement: That sounds incredibly overwhelming, juggling endless topics with everything else on your plate. How does this impact other areas of your life or your future goals?

client(guiding): It's really affecting my other classes because I'm falling behind on those assignments. Plus, I'm worried it's going to hurt my grades overall, which stresses me out about my future plans.
Balancing everything sounds like an uphill battle right now. How do you see things changing in a way that supports your goals and eases some of this stress?

client(guiding): I'm hoping I can find a better balance, maybe by creating a more structured schedule or getting help with time management. I just want to not feel so trapped by it all and be able to focus on other important things too.

statement.reasoning: The client has expressed a specific change goal of creating a structured schedule for better balance and has reflected on the impact of their current behavior on future goals. There is evidence of Change Talk, and the client shows readiness by articulating a need for support with time management. The conversation has explored life with and without change, suggesting readiness to move to specific action planning.

dialogue.statement: Creating a better balance sounds like a helpful way to reduce stress and focus on your goals. What are some steps you could take to build a structured schedule or improve time management? Options might include scheduling specific times for Aleks, seeking a tutor, or using a planner. How would you like to approach this?

client(choosing): I've been thinking about trying to set strict time slots for when I work on Aleks, maybe only in the afternoons. Also, getting a planner to track my assignments for all my classes might help. A tutor sounds good too if I can find one that fits my schedule.

Setting specific time slots for Aleks and using a planner to track assignments are excellent strategies to consider. Engaging a tutor could also provide the personalized support you're looking for. What steps do you think are most doable to start with, and how might you monitor your progress to ensure you're staying on track?

client(choosing): I think starting with the planner is the most doable. I can write down all my assignments and deadlines so I have a clear picture of what's coming up. I could try the time slots for Aleks next and see how that goes. I'll just have to check in with myself weekly to see if it's working or if I need to tweak the plan.

statement.reasoning: The client has established a clear goal and an actionable plan by deciding to use a planner and set time slots for Aleks. Barriers and self-monitoring have been discussed, and the client shows readiness with commitment to take initial steps and self-monitor progress.

dialogue.statement: It sounds like you've got a thoughtful plan in place with starting the planner to keep track of everything and setting time slots for your Aleks work. Checking in with yourself weekly is a smart way to monitor what's working and what might need adjusting. You've really taken some solid steps towards easing the stress and finding balance. Remember, it's okay to make changes along the way to find what suits you best. Keep up the great effort, and know that you're making progress towards a healthier balance. If you ever feel stuck or need to explore more options, I'm here to support you. Would you like a quick check-in scheduled for a couple of weeks from now to see how things are going?
Yeah, that sounds like a great idea. Having a check-in might help keep me accountable and adjust things if needed. Thanks for your help!

statement.reasoning: The client has identified coping strategies and a structured plan to manage their workload with a weekly check-in scheduled, which fulfills termination goals. The session can naturally conclude given the established plan and follow-up.

concern:
title: Anyone using Aleks math? What are your thoughts on it? (Story)
The concept makes sense, but it is repetitive. All three of my math professors have used aleks due to blended classes. So students Aleks are different from each other. This professor was more annoying due to her giving us so much damn work, I was doing more math than any of my other class work for other classes. My professor once thought it was a good idea to give us 74 topics once, but in a span of two weeks so there was sometime to it. I lost my mind and got up to 53. I ended up passing the class. 

The second one, I did fine in the first half and the topics were a lot less compared to the first class, but I started to be in a deep burnout state and even getting COVID that I gave up and failed the class due to constantly completing Aleks and just saying fuck all to any topics and assignments.

Now my third professor and I’m making up the class. I’ve somewhat came up with a better system to complete them: on average, it’s 24 topics due in a span of 3-4 days. Of those three days, I complete six topics a day. I’m still in that system. Slipped a bit because I have to put my attention to two other classes and somewhat procrastinated. But now I’ve realized I’ve put so much time in Aleks, I’m somewhat behind in other classes. And I wanted to try and enjoy my weekend whilst maintaining Aleks and I’m seeing a module that is due March 5 of next month that I haven’t touched due to me working on the current module (which I have 33 topics remaining out of 140 I think so I’ve been doing good). 

And I have to work this weekend, but it looks like I may have to call out both days to maintain Aleks and other class work. Which is already bad because I haven’t been working as much recently. 

So now I’m just frustrated and confused on my options because Aleks is taking up too much of my time). And I’m not kidding when I say I have had full on panic attacks due to trying to complete Aleks to pass the class with a C or above. Anyone else?
